On the morning of the twenty-fifth, Pierre was leaving Mozháysk.
A high steep hill descended from Mozháysk had a winding road leading out of the town past the cathedral on the right.
A service was being held in the cathedral and the bells were ringing.
Pierre got out of his vehicle and proceeded on foot.
Behind Pierre, a cavalry regiment was coming down the hill preceded by its singers.
A train of carts carrying wounded men from the engagement the day before was coming up toward Pierre.
The peasant drivers were shouting and lashing their horses while crossing from side to side.
Each cart carried three or four wounded soldiers lying or sitting.
The carts jolted over stones thrown on the steep incline to make it like a road.
The wounded were bandaged with rags, had pale cheeks, compressed lips, and knitted brows.
The wounded held on to the sides of the carts as they were jolted against one another.
Almost all wounded stared with naïve, childlike curiosity at Pierre’s white hat and green swallow-tail coat.
Pierre’s coachman shouted angrily at the convoy of wounded to keep to one side of the road.
The cavalry regiment, as it descended the hill with its singers, surrounded Pierre’s carriage and blocked the road.
Pierre stopped, being pressed against the side of the cutting in which the road ran.
The sunshine from behind the hill did not penetrate into the cutting and it was cold and damp.
Above Pierre’s head was bright August sunshine.
The bells sounded merrily.
One of the carts with wounded stopped by the side of the road close to Pierre.
The driver in his bast shoes ran panting up to the cart.
The driver placed a stone under one of the cart’s tireless hind wheels.
The driver began arranging the breech-band on his little horse.
